node.statement: (Uniform exponential bounds under mu_eps^L) CLAIM: For k in {1,2,3}, f in C^inf(T^3), alpha in R, and any delta > 0: sup_{eps > 0} E_{mu_eps^L}[exp(alpha <f, :phi_eps^k:_{C_eps}>)] <= M_L(alpha, f, k) < infinity where M_L depends on alpha, f, k, lambda, m^2, and ||psi||_{C^s} for finitely many s, but NOT on eps. PROOF: By node 1.6.4.3 (Step 1), mu_eps^L = (Z_eps^L)^{-1} exp(-V_eps^L) dmu_0 where V_eps^L = lambda int :phi_eps^4:_{C_eps} dx + delta_m_eps^2 int :(phi_eps - psi_eps)^2:_{C_eps} dx. The potential V_eps^L has the SAME structure as V_eps: (i) The quartic part lambda int :phi_eps^4: dx is identical. (ii) The quadratic part delta_m_eps^2 int :(phi_eps - psi_eps)^2: dx >= 0 (since (phi_eps - psi_eps)^2 >= 0, so :(phi_eps - psi_eps)^2: >= -C_eps(0)). In particular, V_eps^L >= lambda int :phi_eps^4: dx - delta_m_eps^2 C_eps(0)|T^3|. The QUARTIC DOMINATION argument (node 1.6.2.10.2.4) for the bound E_{mu_eps}[exp(alpha <f, :phi^k:>)] <= M works as follows: (1) Use the Boue-Dupuis variational formula to write -log Z_eps and E_{mu_eps}[exp(alpha <f, :phi^k:>)] as variational problems. (2) Apply Young inequality: alpha <f, :phi^k:> <= (k/4) V_eps + C(alpha, f, k) (quartic domination since k <= 3 < 4). (3) The resulting integral is bounded by a factor depending on Z_eps and the Gaussian partition function. Steps (1)-(3) depend on V_eps ONLY through its quartic coercivity: V_eps >= lambda int :phi_eps^4: dx - C (for some constant C independent of eps). Since V_eps^L satisfies the SAME coercivity bound V_eps^L >= lambda int :phi_eps^4: dx - C (with possibly a different constant C depending on psi), the IDENTICAL argument gives: E_{mu_eps^L}[exp(alpha <f, :phi_eps^k:>)] <= M_L(alpha, f, k) with M_L depending on the quartic coupling lambda and the coercivity constant, but uniform in eps. The key point is that the Boue-Dupuis + Young inequality argument is insensitive to the precise form of the quadratic part of the potential -- it uses only the quartic coercivity and the structure of the Gaussian reference measure mu_0. CONSEQUENCE: The uniform integrability of exp(Psi_eps^{ren}) under mu_eps^L (needed in node 1.6.4.4 Step 3(b)) follows by the same Holder + Vitali argument as in node 1.6.3.4: sup_eps E_{mu_eps^L}[exp((1+delta) Psi_eps^{ren})] <= prod_{j=1}^4 M_L(4(1+delta) c_j, f_j, k_j)^{1/4} < infinity. DEPENDENCIES: 1.6.2.10.2.4, 1.6.4.3.
